Comment: Mini tournament game, I go for the Indian.

Tango, anyone? This defense is known as The Black Knights' Tango, also known as the Mexican Defense or Kevitz-Trajkovic Defense. And that right there is all I know about it - at this point, I'm pretty much hoping the GK DB will offer me some good advice from here on out.

White forked the black king and the pawn on b7, gaining a pawn. It's usually a temporary gain, as it's easy enough for black to post a rook on b8, chasing away the queen and winning white's b-pawn in the process.

Expecting 20. f3 f5 and if white defends the backward e-pawn with his queen, then black has Qg5 or even Qf4 (as long as that pawn stays pinned to the king) to bring in the extra firepower to win the pawn.

White played this move, and then resigned, though I'm unconvinced that the white position is so dire. In fact, this opponent resigned 23 games on this date, dropping over 200 points in rating in the process. I hope he's OK. I'll take the win, but it would have been more fun to play it out.
